abstract: Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) is a chronic allergic inflammatory condition of the esophagus associated with elevated esophageal eosinophils. Second only to gastroesophageal reflux disease, EoE is one of the leading causes of chronic refractory dysphagia in adults and children. EoE is a clinicopathologic disorder and the histological portion of the diagnosis requires enumerating the density of esophageal eosinophils in esophageal biopsies, and evaluating additional features such as basal zone hyperplasia is helpful. However, this task requires time-consuming, somewhat subjective manual analysis, thus reducing the ability to process the complex tissue structure and infer its relationship with the patient's clinical status. Previous artificial intelligence (AI) approaches that aimed to improve histology-based diagnosis focused on recapitulating identification and quantification of the area of maximal eosinophil density, the gold standard manual metric for determining EoE disease activity. However, this metric does not account for the distribution of eosinophils or other histological features, over the whole slide image. Here, we developed an artificial intelligence platform that infers local and spatial biomarkers based on semantic segmentation of intact eosinophils and basal zone distributions. Besides the maximal density of eosinophils [referred to as Peak Eosinophil Count (PEC)] and a maximal basal zone fraction, we identify the value of two additional metrics that reflect the distribution of eosinophils and basal zone fractions. This approach enables a decision support system that predicts EoE activity and potentially classifies the histological severity of EoE patients. We utilized a cohort that includes 1,066 biopsy slides from 400 subjects to validate the system's performance and achieved a histological severity classification accuracy of 86.70%, sensitivity of 84.50%, and specificity of 90.09%. Our approach highlights the importance of systematically analyzing the distribution of biopsy features over the entire slide and paves the way toward a personalized decision support system that will assist not only in counting cells but can also potentially improve diagnosis and provide treatment prediction.
